child.pub-comments: Node not named by author; "it is clear that Kam, Mulam (Mulao), and perhaps Then stand somewhat apart from Sui, Mak, and Maonan (see Thurgood, this volume)" (Solnit 1988:223).

child.pub-comments: Author indicates uncertainty that Then falls into this Kam-Mulam subgroup (Solnit 1988:223).

child.pub-comments: The position of Lakkia is the focus of this paper. "Lakkia is spoken by some 8,000 people in the Jinxiu Yao Autonomous county (formerly known as Dayaoshan) of Guangxi" (Solnit 1988:220). The author notes that the language Be (Ong-Be), like Lakkia, seems to be "relatively close to Kam-Tai, at least closer than Hlai" (Solnit 1988:226); however, he does not further incorporate Be into his picture of the subgrouping of Kadai.

child.pub-comments: Author indicates that the Hlai group includes "some eight languages", but does not name all of them or fully describe their subgrouping (Solnit 1988:219).
